t: Isaiah 29
Woe to David’s City
Woe*pn to you, Ariel, Ariel, the*ld city where David settled! Add*ln year to year and*ld let your cycle of festivals go on.
Yet*ln I will besiege Ariel; she*ld will mourn and lament, she*ld will be to me like an altar hearth.
I*ln will encamp against you on all sides; I*ld will encircle you with towers and*ld set up my siege works against you.
Brought*ln low, you will speak from the ground; your*ld speech will mumble out of the dust. Your*ln voice will come ghostlike from the earth; out*ld of the dust your speech will whisper.
But*pn your many enemies will become like fine dust, the*ld ruthless hordes like blown chaff. Suddenly,*ln in an instant,
the*ld Lord*s Almighty will come with*ln thunder and earthquake and great noise, with*ld windstorm and tempest and flames of a devouring fire.
Then*ln the hordes of all the nations that fight against Ariel, that*ld attack her and her fortress and besiege her, will*ln be as it is with a dream, with*ld a vision in the night—

as*ln when a hungry person dreams of eating, but*ld awakens hungry still; as*ln when a thirsty person dreams of drinking, but*ld awakens faint and thirsty still. So*ln will it be with the hordes of all the nations that*ld fight against Mount Zion.
Be*pn stunned and amazed, blind*ld yourselves and be sightless; be*ln drunk, but not from wine, stagger,*ld but not from beer.
The*ln Lord*s has brought over you a deep sleep: He*ld has sealed your eyes (the prophets); he*ld has covered your heads (the seers).
For*p you this whole vision is nothing but words sealed in a scroll. And if you give the scroll to someone who can read, and say, “Read this, please,” they will answer, “I can’t; it is sealed.”
Or if you give the scroll to someone who cannot read, and say, “Read this, please,” they will answer, “I don’t know how to read.”

The*p Lord says: “These*pn people come near to me with their mouth and*ld honor me with their lips, but*ld their hearts are far from me. Their*ln worship of me is*ld based on merely human rules they have been taught.
Therefore*ln once more I will astound these people with*ld wonder upon wonder; the*ln wisdom of the wise will perish, the*ld intelligence of the intelligent will vanish.”
Woe*ln to those who go to great depths to*ld hide their plans from the Lord,*s who*ln do their work in darkness and think, “Who*ld sees us? Who will know?”

You*ln turn things upside down, as*ld if the potter were thought to be like the clay! Shall*ln what is formed say to the one who formed it, “You*ld did not make me”? Can*ln the pot say to the potter, “You*ld know nothing”?
In*pn a very short time, will not Lebanon be turned into a fertile field and*ld the fertile field seem like a forest?
In*ln that day the deaf will hear the words of the scroll, and*ld out of gloom and darkness the*ld eyes of the blind will see.
Once*ln more the humble will rejoice in the Lord;*s the*ld needy will rejoice in the Holy One of Israel.
The*ln ruthless will vanish, the*ld mockers will disappear, and*ld all who have an eye for evil will be cut down—
those*ln who with a word make someone out to be guilty, who*ld ensnare the defender in court and*ld with false testimony deprive the innocent of justice.
Therefore*p this is what the Lord,*s who redeemed Abraham, says to the descendants of Jacob: “No*pn longer will Jacob be ashamed; no*ld longer will their faces grow pale.

When*ln they see among them their children, the*ld work of my hands, they*ln will keep my name holy; they*ld will acknowledge the holiness of the Holy One of Jacob, and*ld will stand in awe of the God of Israel.
Those*ln who are wayward in spirit will gain understanding; those*ld who complain will accept instruction.”
